segment.source: About the Application Virtualization Sequencer
segment.target: About the Application Virtualization Sequencer

segment.source: About the Application Virtualization Sequencer
segment.target: About the Application Virtualization Sequencer

segment.source: About the Application Virtualization Sequencer
segment.target: About the Application Virtualization Sequencer

segment.source: The Microsoft Application Virtualization (App-V) Sequencer monitors and records all installation and setup processes for an application and creates the following files: ICO, OSD, SFT, and SPRJ.
segment.target: The Microsoft Application Virtualization (App-V) Sequencer monitors and records all installation and setup processes for an application and creates the following files: ICO, OSD, SFT, and SPRJ.

segment.source: These files contain all the necessary information about an application so the application can run in a virtual environment on target computers.
segment.target: These files contain all the necessary information about an application so the application can run in a virtual environment on target computers.

segment.source: You can use the Microsoft Application Virtualization (App-V) Sequencer to create virtual applications.
segment.target: You can use the Microsoft Application Virtualization (App-V) Sequencer to create virtual applications.

segment.source: After you sequence an application, it can be streamed to target computers, or target computers can run the virtual application by downloading the contents of the virtual application package and running the application locally.
segment.target: After you sequence an application, it can be streamed to target computers, or target computers can run the virtual application by downloading the contents of the virtual application package and running the application locally.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: To run a virtual application package the target computer must be running the appropriate version of the App-V client.
segment.target: To run a virtual application package the target computer must be running the appropriate version of the App-V client.

segment.source: Virtual application packages run on target computers without interacting with the underlying operating system on the target computer because each application runs in a virtual environment and is isolated from other applications that are installed or running on the target computer.
segment.target: Virtual application packages run on target computers without interacting with the underlying operating system on the target computer because each application runs in a virtual environment and is isolated from other applications that are installed or running on the target computer.

segment.source: This isolation can reduce application conflicts and can help decrease the required amount of application pre-deployment testing.
segment.target: This isolation can reduce application conflicts and can help decrease the required amount of application pre-deployment testing.

segment.source: Sequencer Terminology
segment.target: Sequencer Terminology

segment.source: Application Virtualization drive
segment.target: Application Virtualization drive

segment.source: The application virtualization drive is the default drive (Q: on the target computer from which sequenced applications are run.
segment.target: The application virtualization drive is the default drive (Q: on the target computer from which sequenced applications are run.

segment.source: ICO file
segment.target: ICO file

segment.source: The icon file on the client desktop which is used to launch a sequenced application.
segment.target: The icon file on the client desktop which is used to launch a sequenced application.

segment.source: Installation directory
segment.target: Installation directory

segment.source: The directory used by the sequencer to place installation files during setup.
segment.target: The directory used by the sequencer to place installation files during setup.

segment.source: Open Software Descriptor (OSD) file
segment.target: Open Software Descriptor (OSD) file

segment.source: An XML-based file that instructs the App-V client how to retrieve the sequenced application from the App-V streaming server and how to run the sequenced application in the virtual environment.
segment.target: An XML-based file that instructs the App-V client how to retrieve the sequenced application from the App-V streaming server and how to run the sequenced application in the virtual environment.

segment.source: Package root directory
segment.target: Package root directory

segment.source: The directory on the sequencing computer on which files for the sequenced application package are installed.
segment.target: The directory on the sequencing computer on which files for the sequenced application package are installed.

segment.source: This directory also exists virtually on the computer to which a sequenced application will be streamed.
segment.target: This directory also exists virtually on the computer to which a sequenced application will be streamed.

segment.source: Sequenced application
segment.target: Sequenced application

segment.source: An application that has been monitored by the sequencer, broken up into primary and secondary feature blocks, streamed to a target computer running the App-V client t, and runs a virtual environment.
segment.target: An application that has been monitored by the sequencer, broken up into primary and secondary feature blocks, streamed to a target computer running the App-V client t, and runs a virtual environment.

segment.source: Sequenced application package
segment.target: Sequenced application package

segment.source: The files that comprise a virtual application and allow a virtual application to run.
segment.target: The files that comprise a virtual application and allow a virtual application to run.

segment.source: These files are created after sequencing and specifically include .osd, .sft, .sprj, and .ico files.
segment.target: These files are created after sequencing and specifically include .osd, .sft, .sprj, and .ico files.

segment.source: Sequencing
segment.target: Sequencing

segment.source: The process of creating an application package using the App-V Sequencer.
segment.target: The process of creating an application package using the App-V Sequencer.

segment.source: In this process, an application is monitored, its shortcuts are configured, and a sequenced application package is created.
segment.target: In this process, an application is monitored, its shortcuts are configured, and a sequenced application package is created.

segment.source: Sequencing computer
segment.target: Sequencing computer

segment.source: The computer used to sequence an application.
segment.target: The computer used to sequence an application.

segment.source: Virtual application
segment.target: Virtual application

segment.source: An application packaged by the Sequencer to run in a self-contained, virtual environment.
segment.target: An application packaged by the Sequencer to run in a self-contained, virtual environment.

segment.source: The virtual environment contains the information necessary to run the application on the client without installing the application locally.
segment.target: The virtual environment contains the information necessary to run the application on the client without installing the application locally.

segment.source: Primary feature block
segment.target: Primary feature block

segment.source: The minimum content in a virtual application package that is necessary for an application to run on a target computer.
segment.target: The minimum content in a virtual application package that is necessary for an application to run on a target computer.

segment.source: The content in the primary feature block is identified during the application phase of sequencing and typically consists of the content for the most used application features.
segment.target: The content in the primary feature block is identified during the application phase of sequencing and typically consists of the content for the most used application features.

segment.source: Sequencing Applications
segment.target: Sequencing Applications

segment.source: There are two methods to create and modify virtual application packages in your environment.
segment.target: There are two methods to create and modify virtual application packages in your environment.

segment.source: The first method is by using the Sequencing wizard.
segment.target: The first method is by using the Sequencing wizard.

segment.source: The Sequencing wizard allows you to create new, or modify existing virtual application packages.
segment.target: The Sequencing wizard allows you to create new, or modify existing virtual application packages.

segment.source: For more information about using the Sequencing wizard see, How to Sequence a New Application.
segment.target: For more information about using the Sequencing wizard see, How to Sequence a New Application.

segment.source: The second method is by using the command-line.
segment.target: The second method is by using the command-line.

segment.source: The command-line allows you to create new, or modify existing virtual application packages using the command prompt.
segment.target: The command-line allows you to create new, or modify existing virtual application packages using the command prompt.

segment.source: For more information about using the command line see, How to Manage Virtual Applications Using the Command Line.
segment.target: For more information about using the command line see, How to Manage Virtual Applications Using the Command Line.

segment.source: The Sequencing wizard provides the following functions for creating virtual application packages:
segment.target: The Sequencing wizard provides the following functions for creating virtual application packages:

segment.source: Package Configuration: The Sequencing Wizard prompts for package configuration information necessary to complete the Open Software Descriptor (OSD) file, which is a required file for starting a sequenced application package.
segment.target: Package Configuration: The Sequencing Wizard prompts for package configuration information necessary to complete the Open Software Descriptor (OSD) file, which is a required file for starting a sequenced application package.

segment.source: Application Installation: The Sequencing Wizard gathers information about an application’s installation and startup configurations.
segment.target: Application Installation: The Sequencing Wizard gathers information about an application’s installation and startup configurations.

segment.source: It monitors and records the installation and startup information associated with the application to create the files necessary for a virtual application package.
segment.target: It monitors and records the installation and startup information associated with the application to create the files necessary for a virtual application package.

segment.source: Application Startup: The Sequencing Wizard gathers information for compiling and ordering the blocks of code necessary to perform the initial startup of the sequenced application package on the target computer.
segment.target: Application Startup: The Sequencing Wizard gathers information for compiling and ordering the blocks of code necessary to perform the initial startup of the sequenced application package on the target computer.

segment.source: The compilation of the code block is referred to as the primary feature block.
segment.target: The compilation of the code block is referred to as the primary feature block.

segment.source: Application Virtualization Sequencer Security Considerations
segment.target: Application Virtualization Sequencer Security Considerations

segment.source: The App-V Sequencer runs all services detected at sequencing time using the Local System account and does not enforce security descriptors on service control requests.
segment.target: The App-V Sequencer runs all services detected at sequencing time using the Local System account and does not enforce security descriptors on service control requests.

segment.source: If the service was installed using a different user account or if the security descriptors are intended to grant different user groups specific service permissions, consider carefully whether the service should be virtualized.
segment.target: If the service was installed using a different user account or if the security descriptors are intended to grant different user groups specific service permissions, consider carefully whether the service should be virtualized.

segment.source: In some cases, you should install the service locally to ensure that the intended service security is preserved.
segment.target: In some cases, you should install the service locally to ensure that the intended service security is preserved.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: You should always save virtual application packages in a secure location.
segment.target: You should always save virtual application packages in a secure location.

segment.target: Related topics
